title: 111_s1284
content: The Act may be cited as the "Ensuring One Level of Aviation Safety Act of 2009" and includes the implementation of recommendations from the National Transportation Safety Board. The "Ensuring One Level of Aviation Safety Act of 2009" mandates the implementation of specific recommendations from the National Transportation Safety Board by the Federal Aviation Administration within 180 days. These recommendations cover various aspects such as inspections for general aviation aircraft, low-airspeed alert systems, programs for flight crewmembers with performance issues, aircraft operations in cold or icy conditions, and education programs for air carrier pilots. The Federal Aviation Administration must implement safety recommendations from the National Transportation Safety Board within 180 days. The Administrator will notify Congress of their decision to implement or not, along with the actions planned if implemented. The Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration must submit to Congress notifications regarding pending recommendations from the National Transportation Safety Board within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. This includes recommendations made before the enactment date that have not been implemented yet. SEC. 3. The Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration must present a plan to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The plan should include a certification process for air carriers to confirm receipt of airworthiness directives and other orders from the Administration, as well as a strategy to ensure compliance with these directives and orders. SEC. 4. Safety inspections of regional air carriers will also be conducted. SEC. 4. SAFETY INSPECTIONS OF REGIONAL AIR CARRIERS. The Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration will conduct random, unannounced inspections of regional air carriers at least once a year to ensure compliance with safety standards. Regional air carriers will be defined by the Administrator. SEC. 5. Safety standards for pilot training, hiring, and aircraft operation will be established. The Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration will issue a final rule on training programs within 180 days. They will also revise regulations to increase the minimum flight hours required for commercial aircraft pilots within 1 year. Additionally, regulations will be implemented to address pilot fatigue. The Federal Aviation Administration will prescribe regulations on work hours for pilots to address pilot fatigue within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. They will also require air carriers to develop fatigue management plans and submit them for approval within 1 year. Establishing standards and procedures for the submission and review of fatigue management plans by the Administration. SEC. 7 amends Section 44703(h)(1)(A) of title 49, US Code to include access for air carriers to information about pilot practical test failures. SEC. 8 focuses on oversight of pilot training schools. The Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration must submit a plan to Congress within a year for overseeing pilot schools certified under part 141 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations. This plan includes ensuring curriculum requirements are met and conducting on-site inspections at least once every 2 years.
